title: The North Sea Supply Boat
items.abstract:
<jats:p>American Institute of Mining, Metallurgical, and Petroleum Engineers, Inc.</jats:p>
               <jats:p>This paper was prepared for the SPE-European Spring Meeting 1975 of the Society of Petroleum Engineers of AIME, held in London, England, April 14–15, 1975. Permission to copy is restricted to an abstract of not more than 300 words. Illustrations may not be copied. The abstract should contain conspicuous acknowledgment of where and by whom the paper is presented. Publication elsewhere after publication in the JOURNAL paper is presented. Publication elsewhere after publication in the JOURNAL OF PETROLEUM TECHNOLOGY or the SOCIETY OF PETROLEUM ENGINEERS JOURNAL is usually granted upon request to the Editor of the appropriate journal provided agreement to give proper credit is made. provided agreement to give proper credit is made. Discussion of this paper is invited. Three copies of any discussion should be sent to the Society of Petroleum Engineers office. Such discussion may be presented at the above meeting and, with the paper, may be considered for publication in one of the two SPE magazines.</jats:p>
               <jats:sec>
                  <jats:title>Abstract</jats:title>
                  <jats:p>This paper presents the development of the North Sea supply vessel as from the past, present and future. It gives a brief present and future. It gives a brief statement concerning an anchor handling procedure in the North Sea of a semi-submersible and a large North Sea type tug/anchorhandling/ supply vessel. Special attention is required for a better cooperation between the drilling companies and the supply boat company, in particular during the designing stage.</jats:p>
                  <jats:sec>
                     <jats:title>Introduction</jats:title>
                     <jats:p>The history of the North Sea supply boat cannot be described as being a very long one but at the same time it has seen the introduction of many unique innovations in marine technology.</jats:p>
                     <jats:p>The actual number of supply ships operating in the North Sea area today cannot be accurately assessed as ships are constantly being moved into the area from overseas and assigned to other operational areas. The arrival of new buildings on the scene can also confuse the figures as can the seasonal demands of the construction contractors. However I would estimate that approximately 250 supply boats of varying capability will find employment in the North Sea area during the Summer of 1975. Most offshore support craft activities are nowadays concentrated on the United Kingdom Continental Shelf where the majority of oil and gas discoveries have been made. My own Company has always favoured international involvement and in the 10 years of the Company's history, we have serviced drilling operations offshore Denmark, The Irish Republic, Holland, Norway, Sweden and the United Kingdom.</jats:p>
                     <jats:p>I propose to divide this paper into 3 sections, the past, the present and the future.</jats:p>
                  </jats:sec>
                  <jats:sec>
                     <jats:title>1. THE PAST</jats:title>
                     <jats:p>The first purpose-built supply boat for North Sea duty reared its head during the Spring of 1965.</jats:p>
                  </jats:sec>
               </jats:sec>

items.abstract: <jats:p content-type="fine-print">✓ A report of a patient with a spinal arteriovenous malformation (AVM) supplied from the right hypogastric artery is presented to emphasize the importance of thorough angiographic investigation when a spinal AVM is suspected.</jats:p>

title: Labour Supply and Demand, Absenteeism, and Union Behaviour
Chapter 6. Aggregate Demand, Supply and Prices
Impact and economics of community water supply: A study of rural water investment in Kenya
On the peak‐load pricing of urban water supply
items.abstract: <jats:p>Peak‐load pricing through seasonal price increases without changes in metering and billing practices may produce distortions in efficiency and equity in urban water systems. Demand management models using parameters to evaluate the effect of seasonal price policy upon maximum day sprinkling demands may be misleading because of behavioral constraints to price responsiveness. Proposed are alternative pricing schemes that are likely candidates for improving the operating cost structure and design capacity of water supply systems without violating popular notions of equity.</jats:p>

title: Oil and Security, The Energy Question: An International Failure of Policy and Raw Material Supply in a Multipolar World
Who to put your money on in the industrial laboratory supply field
Undersowing Rice (Oryza sativa) with Stylosanthes guyanensis. III. Nitrogen Supply
items.abstract: <jats:title>SUMMARY</jats:title><jats:p>The growth and nitrogen yield of <jats:italic>Stylosanthes guyanensis</jats:italic> undersown with upland rice were negatively related to level of urea application at Khon Kaen, north-east Thailand. In the absence of applied urea the nitrogen yield of rice monoculture was 3·3 gm./m.<jats:sup>2</jats:sup> whilst the addition of stylo increased nitrogen yield of the association to 9·6 gm./m.<jats:sup>2</jats:sup> Stylo was initially dominated by rice but exploited environmental growth factors more effectively in the latter part of the growing season, accentuating competition for water and phosphorus. Simultaneous stylo and rice sowing reduced rice grain yield by 12 per cent, the greatest reduction occurring at a low level of urea application, mainly due to abortion of spikelets after panicle exsertion.</jats:p>

title: "Rational" Expectations, the Optimal Monetary Instrument, and the Optimal Money Supply Rule
The vascular supply of the cervical skin with reference to incision planning d̊
items.abstract: <jats:title>Abstract</jats:title><jats:p>Wound breakdown, especially following preoperative radiotherapy, is a complication following neck surgery. The anatomy of the blood supply of the neck skin, which is an important factor in neck incision planning, was determined by silicone rubber injection studies. Some of the more common incisions interrupt the cervical blood supply, which descends from the facial and occipital arteries and ascends from the transverse cervical and suprascapular arteries, and this is discussed in relation to wound breakdown.</jats:p>

title: Energy ways around the cash crunch: Options for retracking the U.S. utilities onto their traditional path of adequate and reliable supply
USING REGRESSION ANALYSIS TO REDUCE AGGREGATION BIAS IN LINEAR PROGRAMMING SUPPLY MODELS*
items.abstract: <jats:p>Because methods of eliminating aggregation bias are impracticable, an alternative method is suggested for reducing aggregation bias which uses regression estimates of farm resonrce availabilities as functions of farm size. The estimates are incorporated in a parametric run of the LP problem in which size is parameterized. The method is applied to a case study problem, and the results compared with other methods of demarcating representative farms.</jats:p>

title: A MODEL OF NEW ZEALAND APPLE SUPPLY RESPONSE TO TECHNOLOGICAL CHANGE*
items.abstract: <jats:p>A supply response model for New Zealand apples is specified and equations for new plantings, removals, yields and adoption of an innovation are estimated. The model expands on perennial crop models previously estimated by incorporating the time pattern of adoption of a planting innovation and formulation of a measure of yield expectations given technological change.</jats:p>

title: Comment on ‘Optimal timing, sequencing, and sizing of multiple reservoir surface water supply facilities’ by L. Becker and W. W‐G. Yeh
Growth and yield of sugar beet in relation to potassium and sodium supply
container-title: Journal of the Science of Food and Agriculture
items.abstract: <jats:title>Abstract</jats:title><jats:p>Potassium fertiliser increases yield of sugar beet on most soils in Britain and sodium fertiliser gives a larger increase, whilst decreasing response to potassium. Sugar beet given factorial dressings of these elements was sampled periodically to determine whether they increase yield by similar effects on growth. Three experiments were made at Broom' Barn on a calcareous loam in 1971–73 and the results suggest that the two elements affect growth similarly. Both increased leaf area early in the season, improved the root: top ratio and increased sugar percentage in fresh and dried roots, all factors contributing to increased sugar yield. Analysis of the roots during September to December showed that neither element affected their processing quality; although each element increased its own concentration in the root juice, it proportionately decreased the harmful α‐amino nitrogen concentration.</jats:p>
